lg.l: From shore to shore of Zealand’s land,
There is no fairer, brighter scene; Scene. Whakatipu Waimāori/Lake Wakatipu is a long inland lake, in the south of the South Island.
No nobler spot, or picture grand,
May ever in these isles be seen.
All that’s joyous, fresh and clear,
Doth cling about it, and around,
Charming every object near,
And making heart and pulse to bound.
Shapes of beauty, forms of grace,
Float about on every side;
Airy nothings, seen in space,
Come reflected on its tide.
Dark and massive, shadow back
Mountains great; Mountains great. Whakatipu Waimāori/Lake Wakatipu is surrounded by mountains, including the Kawarau/Remarkables Range. and greater still,
Marking, by their mighty track,
The terraced slopes of vale and hill.
Waters deep, and dark, and blue,
Mirror clouds of purest white;
And show unbroken, sharp, and true,
Snow-clad peaks of wondrous height.
Blackest shapes of mountains bold,
Bluest skies, each leaping stream—
Birthplace these of magic gold Gold. The Otago gold rush, which began in 1861, included locations along the Kawarau River, which is the only outflow of Whakatipu Waimāori/Lake Wakatipu. —
All are there—a blended dream.
Pastures green, and countless flocks Flocks. The extensive grasslands east of the Southern Alps were fully exploited for sheep farming by the mid-1860s.
Roam o’er hills and valleys deep,
Browsing on the jutting rocks,
Or by its crystal streams do creep.
Homesteads snug, unknowing tell
The wanderer yet of joy and peace;
Each wreath of smoke from wooded dell,
Unwinds from round his heart a crease.
Health and freedom supreme reign,
Undivided in their sway;
Each alone asserts its claim
To act its part in fullest play.
Summer heats, nor winter snows,
Change or alter not their powers;
But sweet is every wind that blows:
Yes! sweet as Spring time’s sweetest flowers.
Contrasts meet and harmonize—
Skies and waters, mountains too—
Each with each doth sympathise,
The towering hills and waters blue.
Distance, seen through azure space,
Present seems to wondering eye;
Strange, weird objects seem in place,
And long-forgotten scenes draw nigh.
Strange enchantment that the spell,
As wove around you, taints the air,
And bids the stranger speak, and tell
How thy glory banished care.
Enraptured by thy fairy forms,
Troubles fly, and cares forsake;
Pleasant calms replace life’s storms
In presence of this queenly Lake.
